FRIDAY, JULY 2, 1886.

Gladstone has started on his Scotch campaign, and his journey so far has been characterized by a certain amount of enthusiasm. It is evident that he is still the "old" O'Connell to the English populace, and that his presence is as magnetic as ever.

We trust that no action of the constant trouble taking place from the closing of the old trails, that the Government will take some steps in the matter. Many families make a living by clearing old trails, and this causes endless inconvenience to those cases ending in blows. The trail on Wednesday last is one of the few instances where the participants into the affair are known, and as the magistrates appear not to have done anything in the matter will be settled at the next High Court one way or another.

The news with regard to the progress of the Hudson's Bay post has of late been of a most favorable character, and there seems reason to hope, notwithstanding the long delay, that the end in view will yet be accomplished. We have always been devoutly hoped that such will prove to be the case. Too much importance should not, however, be attached to the fact that the cargo of the Hudson's Bay vessel Prince of Wales, York Factory, as such a successful expedition, has been delayed upon prior to Mr. Sutherland's departure for England.

The Winnipeg Sun says: The newspapers in the east are busily engaged discussing the result of the new frequencies exchanged and the North West election, and the close kept up for some time, but on the whole leading thereof. That the election was a success of appeal was the practical issue and that the electors wished to return upon the Conservative opposition to the place where the firmest vote was almost blotted out is not denied. In but one county in the province blanket, presumably belonging to the entire Conservative ticket, the wounded Indian. One night while Mr. Gaudry was camping near the town two of his horses were to the result of the first Dominion election off. Just before retiring for the evening Mr. Gaudry heard a noise outside his tent and went out to investigate, when he came upon two Indians standing about a fire. One of them was the only Conservative in sight, Mr. Gaudry connected with the contest to Gaudry's son fired two shots at each of the Indians, thought they had killed them. Mr. Gaudry further proved that the Indians were not dead, but lost in the darkness, Dominion will no longer follow party. At Glaichen a number of lodges without reason. In other respects belonging to Big Bear are compared, the result is a deplorable one. We do not now discuss the question of Nova Scotia, which is now being very properly discussed. The streets are filled with excitement, the Government is doing all it can to suppress the movement. We say, therefore, that it cannot possibly be realized. Our federation cannot be repealed. For good or for ill the union has taken place and must result in a new make. It is not true that all that we would desire the full possibilities of a large extent in that direction, that is the case of every country where it exists, and that exists in Canada. We must therefore be content to neutralize the effects of the other instead of having regard merely to the national side of things.

There seems reason to suspect the same movement on the part of some of our citizens in regard to the Indians, and although we have not heard any official account of their movements, we may have seen such a state of affairs as might have been expected. We have seen nothing with reference to their actions to the west of us. But should these come to prove incorrect, if we judge the correctness of these in our own minds. Of course a great deal of it may be due to the recent unsettled state since the last rebellion, but when we see them thus so greatly increased, it is impossible to believe, and at all events it is impossible to believe that twenty tepees with men possessing and representing from one place to the other all night of the night, were merely tents for shelter. It is evident to the eye that they are in the habit, previous to the last outbreak, of getting to their places of abode during dark, we cannot help thinking that there is something of a serious nature at the bottom of it, and should our suspicions prove correct, though we do not wish to create alarm, yet it is the duty of everyone to be on the alert and prepared to meet any emergency that may arise by the rising of these Indians.

We take the following from the Medicine Hat Times: On the 15th June the Indians in the Cypress Hills, charged at the house of Mr. Ritchie and demanded a band of American Indians amongst a large number from their quarters. On proceeding to the Indians' encampment the corporal ordered the Indians to leave their business in the territory, and the Indians received a shower of bullets, which, fortunately, fell short of their mark. Ritchie then commenced his march for the fort, and some Indians discharged a volley of bullets at him, wounding a corporal and wounded several others. We are informed that the Indians were dispersed by a volley of bullets from the fort.

THE VERY LATEST NEWS BY WIRE.

(By Special Telegraph.)

WINNIPEG, June 28.—Teener, Gau-

dard, Ham and Stone carriages, ex-

pected at arrival tonight.

The first through train from Montreal to Vancouver leaves the former city at six o'clock this evening. It will be a consist of two engines, three baggage cars, two dining cars, one sleeping car, two immigrant sleepers, two first class cars, two sleep-

ing cars and passenger dining cars.

Arrival on Thursday morning at six o'clock and reach its destination the next day.

Hon. Alexander Morris, formerly Lt.

Governor of Manitoba, is visiting Win-

nipeg.

The following additional Liberal can-

didates have been nominated for the

provincial Legislature: Mountain, T. Green-

way, Turtle Mountain, Young; West-

mount, Murray; Minnedosa, C.

McKee; Winnipeg Junction, J. A.

Gibson; defeated Teener at White

Lake, on Saturday, and lowered

timetable records seven and a half.

Ex-Vice President Davis of the United

States has died.

Gladstone is said to be preparing an-

other manifesto defining the utmost con-

cessions to radical opponents.

Two miles of new telegraph line be-

tween Battleford and Edmonton will be

constructed before fall. Work is pro-

gressing, one thousand iron poles will be

soon erected.

A proclamation is published to the

effect that the Indians hold land of chief

John Smith on their reserve can be sold

from the land of chief James Paskam, north of White

Lake, and the land of chief

Grandeau, south of White Lake, sufficiently advanced to admit some of

the members taking advantage of the

government offer made in July, 1886,

and become enfranchised if after the time

required they are found qualified.

The said Indian Act is to extend and

apply to them.

The Cabinet were engaged Saturday

settling the Colonization Company ques-

tion. The question of whether or not

a settlement will be made on the award

of the hand at the rate of two dollars per

acre to the company's stockholders have not

been discussed. The government has

not sufficient information of the most

respecting placing farmers on the

respective limits. Companies which

have expressed a willingness to sell

lands and take steps to promote immi-

gration will be more liberally dealt with.

Winnipeg, July 30.—On the arrival

of the first through train tomorrow

morning the military will turn out, and

the artillery will fire a salute. An address to

Speaker introduced by will be read by the

Mayor.

A newspaper with the words "Winnipeg

greeting" will be sent through to the

Pacific Coast.

Teener, in the course of an interview

broadcast Tuesday afternoon, took time

to say he was too busy for one of his

papers has spoiled him.

Sept. Egan, who has just returned

from Europe, says he is in the best

condition. The Government has

a large number of men at work at present, engaged in clearing the

line between Battleford and Edmonton.

Gibson who has the direction of the

international telegraph wires, says the

route has been considerably changed

and become somewhat longer. The line

from Battleford will run in a more nor-

therly direction, and will be used as a

marker reserve from Pitt, and taken in

Victoria and other new points including

Swan River and Fort Macleod. On account

of the absence of good timber in certain

districts, over one thousand iron poles

will be needed along the route, more for

experiencing the weathering than

elsewhere.

Detroit still leads in the international

match with Chicago by three games and

with New York by two.

Elections in thirty-nine English dis-

tricts take place Friday. Ministers

expect of obtaining a small

majority. At the same time, the

majority for the Government is ex-

pected to be twenty. Unanimous is com-

monplace, but their estimates

ranging from forty to sixty.

Meeting at Conservative clubs in the

eastern Gladstone.

Elections will be held in 30 districts

on Friday next, including Manchester,

Liverpool, Leeds, Aberdeen and Bristol.

The contest is expected to be unusually

close throughout Great Britain, against 50 Gladstones.

The Marquis of Lorne will contest

Surrey East, and Lord Kitchener the

HUDSON'S BAY ROUTE.

The London Canadian Gazette contains the following with regard to the proposed Hudson's Bay Railway: "This proposal seems to be considered likely to be productive of great benefits immediately in regard to this project, though we find it difficult to believe that any practical benefits can result from such a proposal, as on each step, far as he would, in our opinion, be most assuredly brought about by the probability that the Hudson's Bay Company has never been proved, the government inquiry into that subject has not been made in the other way, but it seems to be admitted that the land through which the railway would pass is of but little value agriculturally, and that the people who live there will not be able to maintain their own existence, and they will certainly not be able to maintain their property in whatever fate may befall them."

The Gazette assumes to speak more positively concerning a matter of which it either knows nothing, or with regard to which it is most unfairly prejudiced. It seems to us more than incorrect to say that the practicability of the Hudson's Bay route has not been tested. The Government itself has stated that the Government's inquiry into the subject points the other way.

The Government's committee has been established to the entire satisfaction of all who have really interested themselves in the matter. It has been constituted, in fact, by the experience of Hudson's Bay Company and others of almost every description, the last two months past. There is every reason to believe that of the two routes, the Hudson's Bay is better and more suitable than the Lake route. There were always those to be found who would dispute the practicability of the latter until it had been tested by actual experience. The evidence collected by Lieut. Gordon in the Albert district was sufficient to prove another route, as any one candidly reading his report to the Government and considering the circumstances must acknowledge.

There is no doubt that the land through which the proposed railway will pass is not highly productive agriculturally. A great deal of it is a first-class farming and grazing country. The Government's committee will have to depend for its success upon the magnificent stretch of prairie country both north and south of the international boundary, whose products it will carry to the British market. The wheat of almost the whole Canadian-American west will pass over it.

The best advice which the Government could give the company is necessarily to be selected along the exposed line. Over 12,000 acres of the land which they can acquire in the Northwest will become the property of the company on the completion of each and every mile of road. If, therefore, the company should choose to make a financial expenditure, they need not worry about the future; we may well trust that the future of the Canadian railway enterprise.

With the exception of the Manitoba government, the Government's statement regarding the Hudson's Bay route is practically demonstrated in their offer to guarantee four and a half millions of the company's capital. The "doubts" of the irresponsible and utterly uninformed Canadian Gazette appear altogether groundless.

No doubt a Hudson's Bay Railway prospectus has been issued, as also beyond prospectus. These will correspond with what "dearly" deserves sympathy, but it will be for a reason very different from that immediately by the Gazette. It will be because they have been forced to regret their confidence in the undertaking. The Hudson's Bay route will shortly be abandoned by the company, notwithstanding the Gazette's terrible, if bitter opposition to it.

ROUGH ON MORMONS.

The Utah bill is amended by the house judiciary committee, in some respects strengthening it when referred to the senate. Among the noticeable amendments of the new measure are the abolition of the federal charter of the Mormon church and its dissolution and the amendment of the incorporation of the church so as to make it subject to the amendment of the territorial militia laws and the provisions uprating the Mormon legislative system and equalizing the status of religious organizations.

The annulment of the charters of the Mormon church and immigration society makes away with a substantial part of the political system and other proposals destroy the power of the Mormon to reduce the church and influence the general elections by the territorial offices with Mormon churchmen.

To prevent this, Gov. Murray vetoed the bill, saying that the church cannot maintain this organization, and that is by no means the least good act that the church has done for the advancement of civilization when he was in office. The placing of the Mormon church on an equality with other religious organizations tends to the trend of prosperity, a terrible threat to the hierarchy, which may be recognized with the bill goes into effect. The church will wind up this Mormon organization by sweeping legislation within counties and cities. This is a cruel thing. The bill is severe, but in the main it is in the right direction. Religion must be protected from the encroachments of a mongering hierarchy, based upon local laws and local customs, puts in the religious organization the same rights as the democratic party.

The system must be slain. — St. Paul Pioneer Press.

GENERAL NEWS.

To promote economy the French Government has established savings banks in connection with the post offices. There are now thirty-three of these, three hundred and fifty thousand persons whose names are on the books have an average of about five francs each.

Superintendent Palmer leaves for Paris, France, where he proposes forming a company to operate a ranch in the Far West. Firsthand news extensive factory fire in Toronto was brought to the ground. The fire was caused by a spark from one hundred thousand, chiefly covered by insurance.

Lieut. Winter, of the Governor General's Foot Guards, has been presented by the other officers of the same regiment with a sword and sword for his bravery in Egypt and the North-west.

Sir John's programme at present arranged is to proceed to Winnipeg direct from Ottawa over the C. P. R. route, and then to go by steamer to Edmonton, where he will remain another week. From that point he will make a pilgrimage to the scene of his capture by the Indians.

After that he goes on to the Pacific coast.

In an interview with the Minister of Fisheries, the latter said that circulars had been sent out. Before they did, he would accomplish by moderate means the end sought for. He said the minister had been instructed to allow him to capsize and natural officers on May 7th had been consulted and in their opinion the vessel was entitled to supply a copy of an unofficial circular to any American fishermen found in Nova Scotia waters. If the vessel was found inside the three mile limit fishing regulations would be enforced, then a Canadian officer would be placed on board the boat to see that the regulations were observed.

A public meeting was held in Moncton when resolutions of sympathy with the fishermen were adopted. The mayor has been instructed to send a message to the minister authorizing him to draw at sight for £300.
